title: Molecular-Resolution Electron Imaging of Defects and Dynamics at the Ice-Water Interface
content: Water crystallization into hexagonal ice (type Ih) is one of the most critical processes relevant to the Earthâ€™s environment and human activities. However, despite recent breakthroughs in imaging non-equilibrium condensed ice structures [1-4], the ice-water interface has never been imaged at a molecular resolution. This is primarily due to the low stability of the hydrogen bonds in ice under high-resolution microscopy conditions and a lack of methods to prepare compatible samples.
